Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: I glanced at the clock, knowing my shift would end soon. My last client, Mrs. Lee, smiled at me in the mirror. “Could you just trim a bit more off the fringe?” she asked, her tone gentle. I nodded, reaching for my scissors, but my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from my wife: “Rough day, nothing major, just need to talk.” I pictured her sitting on the couch, waiting for me to come home and listen, to be present, to care. But Mrs. Lee was watching me expectantly, trusting me to get her hair just right, as always. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in—my wife needed my attention and comfort, but my client deserved my focus and skill. My hands hesitated, scissors poised, as my mind raced between the salon and my living room, torn by the quiet demands of two people who mattered to me in different ways.
